coredata.dc:title: Ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte reinforced by in-situ polymerization of PEGDA interlayer for lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: He, Min
Mo, Changyong
Lu, Zecheng
Huang, Yonghao
Qiu, Zhancai
Li, Weishan
Liao, Youhao
coredata.dc:description: The solid electrolyte -is regarded as the proprietary electrolyte to solve the safety problem of high-energy-density lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Combined with the both advantages of inorganic ceramic and polymer electrolytes, the ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte of 15 wt% Li0.33La0.557TiO3-in-poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafiuoropropylene) (LLTO-in-P(VdF-HFP)) is proposed. Since the severe lithiation reaction between LLTO ceramic and lithium metal anode, in situ polymerization of degradable poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) as protective layer on the surface lithium metal is constructed, which not only effectively avoids the side reaction, but also suppresses the growth of lithium dendrites. Under the premise of ensuring the safety of solid state LMBs, trace liquid electrolyte is added into the electrolyte/electrode interface to reduce solid-solid interfacial resistance. The unique design of solid electrolyte combined with protective lithium anode is beneficial to the stable cycling of Li||Li symmetric cells for more than 700 h under current density of 0.2 mA cm−2, compared with only 200 h cycling life for the same electrolyte using the bare lithium anode. The assembled Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cell exhibits a specific discharge capacity of 176 mAh g−1 at 0.2C rate between 3.0 and 4.35 V, maintaining 90.6% of initial capacity after 200 cycles. Therefore, the developed solid electrolyte with unique protected lithium anode exhibits potential application in high-energy-density solid LMBs.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Synthesis schematics for the preparation process of P(VdF-HFP)/Li0.33La0.557TiO3 composite solid electrolyte and the matched lithium anode protected by PEGDA interlayer that is constructed by in situ UV polymerization. The interface between solid electrolyte and solid electrode was wetted with trace liquid electrolyte (LE) to reduce their interfacial resistance.

(a) XRD patterns, (b) FTIR spectra, (c) Strain-stress curves and (d) TGA curves for P(VdF-HFP)/Li0.33La0.557TiO3 composite solid electrolytes doped with different contents of LLTO particles. PVH-0: Pure P(VdF-HFP); PVH-5: P(VdF-HFP)-5%LLTO; PVH-10: P(VdF-HFP)-10%LLTO; PVH-15: P(VdF-HFP)-15%LLTO; PVH-20: P(VdF-HFP)-20%LLTO.
Optical photographs of thermal shrinkage for commercial polyethylene (PE) membrane and P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite solid electrolytes treated at different temperatures for 0.5 h.
(a) Ionic conductivity of P(VdF-HFP) based composite electrolytes with different content of LLTO and (b) ignition test of PVH-15 electrolytes wetted with various volume of liquid electrolyte.

(a) Dependence of temperature and ionic conductivity of SS||SS coin cell and (b) linear sweep voltammograms of Li||SS coin cell (scanning rate: 1 mV s−1) for various electrolytes. Electrochemical impedance spectra and chronoamperometry curves of Li||Li cells, and the change of interfacial resistance with storage time of Li||Li cells for (c, e) PVH-0 and (d, f) PVH-15 electrolyte.
(1) Surface and (2) cross-sectional SEM images for (a) PVH-0, and (b) PVH-15 electrolyte. (c) Optical photographs of PVH-15 electrolyte undergoes bending, folding and unfolding states.

(a) Cyclic performance of symmetrical Li||Li cells for PVH-15 electrolyte without or with PEGDA protective layer at the current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 with Li plating/stripping capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2. (1) Surface and (2) cross-sectional SEM image of (b, d) fresh and (c, e) cycled Li anode dissembled from Li||Li cells (b, c) without or (d, e) with PEGDA protective layer.

(a) Cyclic stability at 0.2C rate and (c) rate capacity of Li||Li0.6Ni0.2Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cells using PVH-15 electrolyte between 3.0 V and 4.35 V, and (b, d) selective charge/discharge curves for the cell with PEGDA protective layer.

head.ce:title: Ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte reinforced by in-situ polymerization of PEGDA interlayer for lithium metal battery

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author at: School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The solid electrolyte -is regarded as the proprietary electrolyte to solve the safety problem of high-energy-density lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Combined with the both advantages of inorganic ceramic and polymer electrolytes, the ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte of 15 wt% Li0.33La0.557TiO3-in-poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafiuoropropylene) (LLTO-in-P(VdF-HFP)) is proposed. Since the severe lithiation reaction between LLTO ceramic and lithium metal anode, in situ polymerization of degradable poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) as protective layer on the surface lithium metal is constructed, which not only effectively avoids the side reaction, but also suppresses the growth of lithium dendrites. Under the premise of ensuring the safety of solid state LMBs, trace liquid electrolyte is added into the electrolyte/electrode interface to reduce solid-solid interfacial resistance. The unique design of solid electrolyte combined with protective lithium anode is beneficial to the stable cycling of Li||Li symmetric cells for more than 700 h under current density of 0.2 mA cm−2, compared with only 200 h cycling life for the same electrolyte using the bare lithium anode. The assembled Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cell exhibits a specific discharge capacity of 176 mAh g−1 at 0.2C rate between 3.0 and 4.35 V, maintaining 90.6% of initial capacity after 200 cycles. Therefore, the developed solid electrolyte with unique protected lithium anode exhibits potential application in high-energy-density solid LMBs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Compared to conventional lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) using graphite anodes, lithium metal batteries (LMBs) applying lithium metal as anode has much higher energy density, which expects to solve the range anxiety problem in electric vehicles [1–3]. However, the current liquid electrolyte based LMBs using flammable carbonate solvent with low flash point brings about great safety hazards to the battery [4,5], exacerbated by the formation of dendritic lithium because of uneven deposition/dissolution of metallic lithium. Replacing the liquid electrolyte by solid electrolyte without any solvent should be the most effective way to solve the safety issue of LMBs [6,7]. Moreover, stronger rigidity of solid electrolyte shows a better ability to block the dendrite puncture than the polyolefin separator in traditional LIBs, further ensuring the safety of LMBs. Therefore, the solid electrolyte is considered as the exclusive electrolyte for LMBs [8–9,10].

Generally, solid electrolytes are composed of polymer or/and ceramic materials. Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), such as poly(ethylene glycol) (PEO), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVdF), poly(vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (P(VdF-HFP)), poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC), have the obvious advantages in flexibility and machinability, which greatly eliminates the interfacial resistance between solid electrode and electrolyte [11,12]. As a traditional SPE, PEO shows good compatibility with lithium anode, but low ionic conductivity at room temperature and narrow oxidative stability limit its further development in high-voltage LMBs [13,14]. The F-rich copolymer, for example, P(VdF-HFP) has attracted the wide attentions because the stronger bond energy of CF expects to extent the oxidative potential of prepared SPE [15], making it become possible to be used in high-voltage LMBs to increase the energy density of assembled battery.

Fortunately, the relatively low ionic conductivity of SPE at room temperature can be compensated by doping lithium-containing active inorganic ceramic particles to obtain the composite solid electrolyte, although the ceramic solid electrolyte with brittleness and rigidity properties gives larger interfacial resistance to the assembled LMBs [16]. Among the reported lithium-containing ceramic materials, perovskite-type Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) not only shows high ionic conductivity at room temperature, but also has low preparation cost owning to the relative cheap price of raw materials and environmental friendliness [17,18]. In this work, P(VdF-HFP) polymer with high oxidation stability is selected as the main parts of solid electrolyte, while a suitable content of active ceramic particles LLTO is added to improve the characterization of ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte.

Nevertheless, the formation of less conductive Ti3+-based-compound through the violent reduction reaction between Ti4+ in LLTO and active lithium metal results in severe damage to both structures of electrolyte and electrode, accompanied by the decreased ionic conductivity of electrolyte and the deteriorated cycle performance [19,20]. Mixing LLTO ceramic particles into the polymer matrix can largely reduce the direct contact area with lithium anode. In order to completely eliminate the possibility of reduction reaction, coating the LLTO particles by polymer or building the polymer blocked layer that only allows specific ions to pass through should be the effective tactics to isolate the directly contact between LLTO and lithium anode.

Accordingly, Guo group prepared LLTO/PVdF composite electrolyte that contacted with 4.25 V high-voltage LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 cathode, while the other LLTO/PVdF layer using the polydopamine (PDA) polymer coated LLTO particles was faced to lithium anode to prevent the reduction reaction of LLTO [21]. Due to the specific structure of solid electrolyte wetted by trace liquid electrolyte, the assembled symmetrical Li||Li coin cell and Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cell yields an excellent cycling stability at the high temperature of 60°C. Nevertheless, the cyclic performance and rate capacity of full cell under room temperature did not present, maybe due to the poor ionic conductivity of PDA-coated LLTO particles that cannot rapidly transport the lithium-ions. Similar work had also been reported for PEO/LLTO composite electrolyte coated with PVdF based gel polymer electrolyte that contains sufficient liquid electrolyte on its both sides, but the thickness of 150 μm for the sandwich electrolyte is not conducive to the energy density of LMBs [22]. To reduce the thickness of electrolyte without sacrificing the blocking function, directly coating the thin polymer on the surface lithium metal as an additional protective layer should be another simple strategy [23,24]. Therefore, selecting the appropriate polymer coating layer becomes the key point for the application of LLTO ceramic in LMBs.

Degradable poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) that contains a large number of flexible segments of −CH2−CH2−O− provides sufficient conductive routes for the transfer of lithium ions [25,26]. At the same time, the inherent cross-linked network structures of PEGDA gives the superior mechanical strength and dimensional stability for the prepared electrolyte. In addition, the PEGDA also enables the reductive stability with lithium anode [27], which is considered as an ideal polymer buffer layer to separate the LLTO from lithium metal. Usually, the isolated layer is built by ex situ method, which is not in good contact with the solid electrolyte and solid electrode. The large interface resistance is not conducive to the transport of lithium ions, thus affecting the electrochemical performance of battery.

In recent years, the in-situ polymerization method to construct the buffer layer between solid electrolyte and electrodes has been widely concerned. It not only prevents the adverse side reactions on the surface of lithium metal, but also facilitate the construction of mechanically stable and effective electrolyte/electrode interface [28,29]. Usually, the elastic organic buffer layer is a good candidate to be applied on the cathode side. For example, the cyclic carbonate urethane methacrylate (CUMA) polymer provides high oxidative stability, which is benifical to the high-voltage cathode, while the polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) layer is used on the anode side because of its good compatibility with Li metal. The constructed mechanochemically stable interfacial layers by in-situ polymerization on both cathode and anode side achieve close contact between solid electrolyte and electrodes, contributing to the cyclic stability of assembled battery [30]. Furthermore, after consideration for the safety of the polymer buffer layer and the transport ability of lithium ions, Xiang group in-situ polymerized PEGDA based electrolyte between cathode and solid electrolyte, which has both high mechanical stability and high ionic conductivity, yielding the long cycle stability of LMBs [31].

Inspired by the above pioneered work, the in situ polymerization method is adopted to rapidly synthesize a PEGDA thin layer on the surface lithium anode in this work. It not only prevents LLTO particles from directly reacting with the metal lithium, but also reduces the interface resistance between solid electrolyte and solid electrode. Without affecting the safety performance of battery, a small amount of liquid electrolyte as wetting agent is added on both sides of composite solid electrolyte to further minimize the interfacial resistance, expecting that the LLTO-in-P(VdF-HFP) solid electrolyte combined with the PEGDA coated lithium anode can be used in high-voltage LMBs. The results suggest that the Li||Li symmetric cell and Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cell protected by the PEGDA interlayer yields the excellent electrochemical performance, indicating the PEGDA is an ideal protected material for lithium anode insolid LMBs. Therefore, the unique combination of P(VdF-HFP)/Li0.33La0.557TiO3 solid electrolyte and the PEGDA protective layer could have the promising applications in high-energy-density LMBs.

Poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafiuoropropylene) (P(VdF-HFP)) powders (Mw = 455,000), lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) (99.9%), N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (99.8%), acetone and N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) were all purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., while poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) (Mw = 700, 98%) and diphenyl (2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl) phosphine oxide (TPO) (97%) were from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., which were used directly without further processing. The used liquid electrolyte (LE) was 1 M LiTFSI in the solvents of ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC)/ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) (3/2/5 in weight) (supplied by Guangzhou Tinci Materials Technology Co. Ltd.).

Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) powders were fabricated by traditional high temperature solid phase reaction. Before mixing, the precursors (Beijing InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd.) of Li2CO3, TiO2 and La2O3 were dried at 900°С to completely remove the impurities. Then the precursors were mixed together with the stoichiometric ratio in ethanol solvent. To compensate for the loss of lithium source during high-temperature reaction, 10 wt% excess Li2CO3 was used in the above mixture. After 12 h of ball milling, the precursor was transferred into the vacuum oven under 80°С for 12 h. The regrind mixture was then added to alumina crucible and calcined at 1200°С for 12 h in the air atmosphere. After naturally cooling to room temperature, LLTO powders were ball milled for 12 h to obtain the nano-size products. To gain the LLTO cylindrical pellets, the LLTO powders were pressed under 40 MPa for 5 min and the thickness of the prepared pellets was 180 μm.

The P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite solid electrolyte was prepared by solution-casting method. The mixtures of P(VdF-HFP) and LiTFSI salt with the weight ratios of 2:1 was dissolved in the mixed solvents of DMAc and acetone by the volume ratios of 3:7. Subsequently, different weight ratios of LLTO was dispersed in the above slurry and stirred for 12 h. After coating the obtained slurry onto a Tefon template, the solid electrolytes were prepared by drying at 60°С for 24 h under vacuum. The obtained electrolytes were orderly named as PVH-0, PVH-5, PVH-10, PVH-15 and PVH-20 based on the contents of LLTO in P(VdF-HFP) polymer for P(VdF-HFP)-0%LLTO, P(VdF-HFP)-5%LLTO, P(VdF-HFP)-10%LLTO, P(VdF-HFP)-15%LLTO and P(VdF-HFP)-20%LLTO.

To prepare the protective layer on the surface of lithium anode, the precursors of PEGDA and liquid electrolyte with the weight ratios of 5:95, and 0.5 wt% TPO initiator were stirred for 2 h. A gelled layer was obtained by in situ polymerization under ultraviolet light with the wavelength of 369 nm for 5 min after homogeneously dropping polymer precursors on the polished lithium metal. Above operations were carried out in an argon-filled glove box (Mikrouna (China) Co., Ltd.). The synthesis schematics of composite solid electrolyte and the surface protective layer on lithium anode were illustrated in Fig. 1 .

The composites of 80% LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2, 10% acetylene black, and 10% PVdF were mixed in NMP solvents. The gained slurry was cast onto Al foil and dried in vacuum oven to obtain the cathode with an average mass loading of 2.5 mg cm−2. The 2025 coin cell with the structures of SS (stainless steel)||SS, Li||SS, Li||Li and Li||cathode sandwiched with solid electrolyte were assembled in the glove box. To reduce the interfacial resistance between solid electrode and electrolyte, a small amount of liquid electrolyte were introduced into both sides of solid electrolyte.

The crystal structure of LLTO particles and composite electrolytes were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements (Ultima IV, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation scanning from 5° to 90° in the rate of 10° min−1. The wavenumber of Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR, Nicolet6700, USA) for the solid electrolyte characterization was from 400 to 1800 cm−1. Mechanical strength of solid electrolytes was determined by a universal testing machine (XLW-EC, Labthink, China) with a stretching speed of 50 mm min−1 using the sample size of 1 cm × 10 cm × 45 μm (thickness). Peel strength of solid electrolytes was also determined by the universal testing machine with a stretching speed of 100 mm min−1 using the sample size of 2 cm × 10 cm × 45 μm. The thermogravimetric analyzer (PerkinElmer TGA 8000, USA) was used to obtain the thermal decomposition temperature of solid electrolytes from 30 to 600°С under 20 mL min−1 airflow with a heating rate of 10°C min−1. The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of electrolytes and electrode were investigated by the field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Quanta 250 FEG, Czech).

The ionic conductivity (σ) of the solid electrolytes was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with an AC amplitude of 10 mV using the frequencies from 105 to 1 Hz. The σ value was calculated from Eq. (1).
(1)
σ = L /
R · S
where L was the thickness and S was the area of solid electrolyte, while R was the resistance obtained from the intersection between the line composed of Nyquist plots and the abscissa of impendence [32].

To obtain the activation energy (E

The oxidative stability of electrolytes were measured by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) (Solartron 1470E, England) using Li||SS coin cell scanning from open circuit potential to 6.0 V at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 under room temperature. The lithium-ion transference number (t
Li

) of electrolytes was obtained by the combination of EIS measurement and DC polarization after applying the potential (△V) of 10 mV in symmetrical Li||Li cells. The Bruce-Vincent Eq.

The symmetrical Li||Li cells were used to evaluate the interfacial compatibility between the electrolyte and Li electrode, which was obtained by monitoring the variation of resistance with storage time. The applied potential was 10 mV using the frequency from 105 Hz to 0.1 Hz. To test the Li-ion plating/stripping stability of Li||Li coin cell, a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 with capacity of 0.2 mAh cm−2 was applied.

The constant current charge/discharge behavior of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cells were carried out on Land test system (CT2001A, Wuhan Land Electronic Co. Ltd., China) under room temperature between 3.0 V and 4.35 V to evaluate the cyclic stability and rate performance. The 0.2C current rate of was used for the long-cycling performance, while the current rates were gradually increased from 0.2C, 0.3C, 0.5C, 1C to 2C, and returned to 0.2C for the rate characterization.

ce:section.ce:section-title: FTIR and mechanical strength of composite solid electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) powders were prepared by traditional high temperature solid-phase reaction method. The surface SEM image in Fig. S1 indicates that the obtained LLTO particles have homogeneous nano-sized morphologies. From the XRD pattern of freshly prepared LLTO powder in Fig. S2, it finds that the crystal diffraction peaks fit well with the standard card of cubic Li0.33La0.557TiO3 structure (JCPDS No. 87–0935), proving the pure phase of the prepared sample. Even after immersed in deionized water or exposed to air for 12 h to simulate the harsh storage environment, LLTO particles still keep original diffraction peaks. The highly stable phase of LLTO makes it become possible to be stored and used in the environment without controlling the content of water and gas atmosphere, which helps to greatly reduce the cost of commercial application.

Furthermore, the cylindrical pellets pressed from LLTO particles were used to measure the ionic conductivity under room temperature. According to Eq. (1), the calculated result from Fig. S3 is 1 × 10−5 S cm−1 for fresh LLTO ceramic. After immersed in deionized water or exposed to air for 12 h, the ionic conductivity of LLTO still kept the level of 0.9 × 10−5 S cm−1 or 1 × 10−5 S cm−1, respectively. Therefore, there is no significant change in the ionic conductivity of LLTO particles before and after treatment, demonstrating the electrochemical stability of ceramic particles under harsh storage conditions.

After doping LLTO particles into the P(VdF-HFP) polymer to form the ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte, the unchanged crystallinity of LLTO in the XRD pattern can be observed in Fig. 2
(a). The presented main diffraction peaks of LLTO in P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO suggest that the composite electrolyte maintains the crystal structure of LLTO. Furthermore, the diffraction peak of wide steamed buns at ∼20° for the pure P(VdF-HFP) (PVH-0) electrolyte ascribes to the high crystalline phase in polymer, which is unbeneficial to the ionic conductivity of solid electrolyte. Fortunately, the peak intensity that reflects the crystallinity degree for P(VdF-HFP) polymer gradually decreases with the increased doping content of LLTO particles. Especially, when the doping content of LLTO reaches 15% for PVH-15 and PVH-20 electrolyte, the increased amorphous region due to the mutual extrusion of the crystalline region in LLTO phase causes the more disordered molecular chains in the polymer, helping to improve the ionic conductivity of the composite electrolyte. The similar result was also reported for the Li1+xAlxGe2−x(PO4)3 ceramic doped P(VdF-HFP) system [35]. FTIR spectra of P(VdF-HFP) with various weight percentages of LLTO are shown in Fig. 2 (b). The peak at 510 cm−1 corresponds to the bending vibration bond of –CF2–, while the peaks at 1200 and 1400 cm−1 attribute to the stretching vibration bond of –CF2– and bending vibration bond of -CH2- for P(VdF-HFP). The unchanged characteristic peaks for the solid electrolyte before and after doping with LLTO particles suggest that the combination of polymer and inorganic ceramics should be the physical mixture instead of chemical reaction [36–38].

Excellent mechanical strength is critical for solid electrolytes for the practical application, which is reflected by the stress-strain curves in Fig. 2 (c). The composite electrolytes have better mechanical properties compared with PVH-0 electrolyte for pure P(VdF-HFP) (5.1 MPa), especially for the PVH-15 electrolyte that has the highest tensile strength of 9.5 MPa. The improved strength is ascribed to the enhanced interfacial bonding strength between P(VdF-HFP) polymer and LLTO particles, since LLTO acted as mechanical attachment points can evenly distribute in the polymer to increase their connectivity. However, when further increasing the content of LLTO to 20 wt%, the agglomerated ceramic particles in PVH-20 electrolyte results in the weakened bond strength, yielding the lower mechanical strength. Therefore, appropriate content of 15% LLTO ceramic particles is conducive to the mechanical strength of composite electrolyte.

In order to further verify the interfacial bonding strength between P(VdF-HFP) polymer and LLTO particles, peel strength tests were carried out using P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite solid electrolytes coated commercial polyethylene (PE) membrane. The higher peel force of solid electrolyte from PE membrane indicates the stronger interfacial adhesion. As indicated in Fig. S4, the peel strength gradually increases along with the LLTO content, and reaches the highest level when the LLTO content is 15%. However, the value decreases after further increases the content of LLTO to 20 wt%. It suggests that the suitable contents of LLTO particles has a positive effect on the interfacial bonding strength. However, the weaken bonding strength for the solid electrolyte with the LLTO content of 20 wt% should be caused by the agglomeration phenomenon of inorganic ceramic particles, which can be clearly observed from the surface SEM images in Fig. S5. It also finds that the ceramic particles can uniformly distribute in the P(VdF-HFP) polymer when the content of LLTO is less than 15 wt%, which is in according with the result of bonding strength, contributing to its electrochemical properties finally.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Thermal stability of composite solid electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: Thermal stability of solid electrolyte is of great significance for the safety performance of batteries to avoid the dangers of thermal runaway by the short circuit. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and area-based dimensional stability under various temperature are implemented to describe the thermal stability of P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite electrolytes. From TGA curves in Fig. 2 (d), the small mass loss before 100°С is due to the decomposition of adsorbed water by LiTFSI salt during sample preparation. After that, the thermal decomposition of pure P(VdF-HFP) and P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite electrolytes from solid into gas state occurs at the temperature of 309°С and 341°С, respectively, which is sufficient to be applied in LMBs with operating temperatures below 100°С.

When thermal runaway happens inside the battery at high temperature, it usually causes the thermal shrinkage of the electrolyte membrane. The direct contact between cathode and anode leads to a short circuit for the battery, aggravating the thermal runaway of the battery and bringing about greater safety accidents. Therefore, the anti-thermal shrinkage ability of prepared solid electrolyte under high temperature is especially important to guarantee the battery safety. In order to simulate its thermal shrinkage under high temperature environment, the electrolyte membranes were placed at the temperatures from 100°С to 160°С for each 0.5 h to observe their area-based dimensional change. For comparison, the commercial polyethylene (PE) membrane used for liquid LMBs are also tested under the same conditions. As shown in Fig. 3 , all electrolyte membranes are dimensionally stable at 120°C. Along with the increased temperature, the PE membrane experiences obvious thermal shrinkage at 140°C, while it exceeds more than 90% thermal shrinkage rate under 160°C. Fortunately, there are no area changes for pure P(VdF-HFP) and P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite solid electrolytes. Even under the high temperature of 160°С, P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite electrolytes shows the dimensional stability, although only a slight shrinkage happen in PVH-0 electrolyte. The improvement in anti-thermal shrinkage ability of P(VdF-HFP)/LLTO composite electrolyte can be attributed to the doping of LLTO ceramic particles with excellent heat resistance, which helps to maintain the dimensional stability at the elevated temperature. Thus, the uniform distribution of LLTO particles in P(VdF-HFP) electrolyte not only improves the mechanical properties, but also exhibits the excellent thermal stability of the electrolyte, contributing to the safety of assembled batteries.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Li-ion conductive behavior of solid electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para:
The ionic conductivity of solid electrolytes plays an important role in the cycle and rate performance of full cell, which was obtained by measuring the Nyquist plots of symmetrical SS||SS cells in Fig. S6. According to Eq.
(1) , the calculated result in Fig. 4
(a) shows that the room temperature ionic conductivity of PVH-0 is 1.5 × 10−5 S cm−1. The value increases with the enhanced LLTO particles content, and reaches the maximum value of 7.7 × 10−5 S cm−1 for PVH-15 electrolyte, then begins to decrease. This is due to the doped fast ion conductor of LLTO particles that helps to build the facile ion channel for the migration of lithium ions. However, the particle agglomeration occurs when further increases the LLTO content in PVH-20 electrolyte, hindering lithium ion transport channels and reducing ionic conductivity.

Although adding proper amount of LLTO particle can improve the ionic conductivity of solid electrolyte, the relatively low value makes it become difficult to apply in commercial battery. Thus, a small amount of liquid electrolyte without affecting the safety of the battery is added to the solid electrolyte. As indicated in Fig. 4 (a), the room temperature ionic conductivity does significantly improve after wetted by the trace liquid electrolyte since the point contact between solid electrolyte and solid electrode is changed to surface contact, resulting in the greatly reduced contact resistance. Moreover, the enhanced trend for various LLTO doped electrolyte wetted with liquid electrolyte is similar for that electrolyte without liquid electrolyte. Especially, the highest values of 5.1 × 10−4 S cm−1 under room temperature for PVH-15 electrolyte wetted with 2 μL cm−2 liquid electrolyte and of 5.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 for that with 4 μL cm−2 liquid electrolyte are achieved, which is sufficient to be applied in current LMBs. The similar ionic conductivity for the PVH-15 solid electrolyte wetted by 2 μL cm−2 or 4 μL cm−2 liquid electrolyte suggests that the smaller value is an ideal amount in consideration of safety issue. From the above results of mechanical strength and ionic conductivity, it can conclude that the doping amount of 15% LLTO in P(VdF-HFP) to form PVH-15 electrolyte should be the best doping dosage, which is selected for the further investigation.

In order to clarify the wetted liquid electrolyte on the influence of safety performance, ignition test were performed for PVH-15 electrolyte wetted with different contents of liquid electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 4 (b), the solid electrolyte cannot be ignited when the liquid electrolyte content is less than 4 μL cm−2. Nevertheless, the solid electrolyte is ignited instantly when it saturated with the liquid electrolyte of 12 μL cm−2, which is also the conventional electrolyte dosage for the liquid LMBs. The results indicate that adding 2 μL cm−2 liquid electrolyte into the solid electrolyte will not affect the safety performance, but does significantly improve the ionic conductivity of electrolyte, which can be practically used in LMBs to reduce the interface resistance.

Fig. 5
(a) depicts the relationship between different temperatures and corresponding ionic conductivity for the various solid electrolyte, while the detail Nyquist plots to calculate the ionic conductivity of solid electrolyte is presented in Fig. S7. Although the ionic conductivity increases along with the elevated temperature, the value of PVH-15 composite electrolyte is always higher than PVH-0 electrolyte at the same temperature. The linear relationship can be observed for the two electrolytes from fitting results, indicating the conductive mechanism of the prepared electrolytes follows Arrhenius behavior. According to Eq.
(2) , the calculated value of activation energy (E
a ) for PVH-15 electrolyte is 15.9 kJ mol−1, which is much lower than that of 36.9 kJ mol−1 for PVH-0 electrolyte. A relatively lower E
a value indicates that the less energy is needed to transfer the ions, resulting in faster movement of Li-ions. This may be due to the reduced crystallinity of P(VdF-HFP) polymer caused by that the LLTO particles break the ordered segment structure of the polymer. In addition, the synergistic effect between LLTO and P(VdF-HFP) is more conducive to promoting the dissociation of lithium salts, which is beneficial to increasing the carrier density to facilitate the conduction of Li-ions [39].

Lithium ion transference number (tLi +) of solid electrolyte is another important parameter to estimate the actual migration ability of cations, not the total ions, which is calculated by Eq.
(3) combining with the EIS plots before and after polarization and chronoamperometry curves in Figs. 5 (c,d). The value of tLi + for PVH-15 electrolyte is 0.40, which is much higher than that of 0.22 for PVH-0 electrolyte. The improved tLi + value of PVH-15 suggests the reduced concentration polarization during charge/discharge process, attributed from the introduction of LLTO ceramic particles that provides the fast ion channels to transport the Li-ions, ensuring the electrochemical performance of solid state LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compatibility of solid electrolyte with electrodes
ce:section.ce:para: The interfacial compatibility between solid electrolyte and Li anode is a decisive factor to ensure the safety and cycle performance of battery, which can be demonstrated by measuring their interfacial impedance change along with the storage time using Li||Li symmetric coin cells at open circuit potential. As presented in Figs. 5 (e, f), the interfacial resistance of the cell with PVH-15 electrolyte increases from 170 Ω after 1 day to 259 Ω after 20 days, while the cell using PVH-0 electrolyte is from 205 Ω to 319 Ω. The value of initial and incremental interfacial resistance of PVH-15 electrolyte assembled coin cell is smaller than that of PVH-0. Especially, the interfacial impedance of PVH-15 electrolyte barely increased from 15 days to 20 days. It indicates that a passivation film is formed on the surface of metal lithium anode to effectively suppress the other side reactions, which is conductive to the cyclic stability of Li-anode assembled cells.

The oxidation stability of solid electrolyte is evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test, which is an important parameter to determine the practical application in high-voltage LMBs. In Fig. 5 (b), it can find that there is not current response for both electrolytes when the potential is less than 4.7 V, indicating the developed solid electrolyte has excellent oxidation stability. Furthermore, the improved oxidative stability of PVH-15 electrolyte by the delayed decomposition potential is due to the high loading of LLTO particles with high immunity to the oxidative decomposition under high voltage condition.

To illustrate the contribution of LLTO particles to the physical performance of PVH-15 electrolyte, the surface and cross-sectional SEM images of electrolyte are exhibited in Fig. 6 . It finds that the PVH-0 electrolyte has an uneven surface in Fig. 6 (a1) due to the solvent volatilization during membrane preparation, which goes against to the electrochemical performance of the battery since the poor contact with electrode could cause a larger interface resistance. Fortunately, the surface morphology of PVH-15 electrolyte in Fig. 6 (b1) is relatively flat without obvious pores. Furthermore, the compact cross-section of PVH-15 electrolyte in Fig. 6 (b2) indicates that LLTO particles are uniformly embedded inside the polymer matrix. The uniform distribution of LLTO particles is beneficial to the ionic transport and the enhancement of mechanical strength. Ascribed from the doping of LLTO particles, the thickness of 45 μm for PVH-15 electrolyte is a little higher than that for PVH-0 electrolyte (38 μm) in Fig. 6 (a2), but the thickness of developed composite electrolyte is suitable to balance the electrochemical performance and the energy density of assembled LMBs. Fig. S8 shows the corresponding SEM elemental mapping and EDS spectrum of PVH-15 electrolyte. The even distribution of the elements in the prepared electrolyte from original materials of P(VdF-HFP) (C, F), LLTO (Ti, La) and LiTFSI lithium salt (S) are beneficial to the electrochemical performance of battery. Moreover, inherited from the excellent malleability of P(VdF-HFP) polymer, the prepared PVH-15 electrolyte exhibits superior flexibility. As indicated in Fig. 6 (c) of the optical photographs, the composite electrolyte can still unfold to maintain its original size and shape when it undergoes the random bending and folding. Therefore, the prepared electrolyte with flexible processing properties make it have wider applications, such as in wearable devices.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cycling performance of Li||Li symmetrical cell
ce:section.ce:para:
From the above-mentioned results, ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte wetted by trace liquid electrolyte can significantly enhance the performance of composite electrolyte. Nevertheless, the LLTO particles in PVH-15 electrolyte are exposed and contact with lithium metal after assembled the solid electrolyte into the battery. The inevitable lithiation reaction is detrimental to the cyclic stability of the cell, which can be facilely solved by in situ polymerization of PGEDA layer on the surface lithium anode to isolate the unpleasant reaction. To verify the contribution of the PEGDA protective layer on the electrochemical characterization, the long-term cyclic stability of PVH-15 electrolyte is evaluated through the plating/stripping of lithium metal in symmetrical Li||Li cells under the constant current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 (capacity: 0.2 mAh cm−2). As shown in Fig. 7
(a), the voltage oscillation of cell with PEGDA protective layer is larger than that of the cell without PEGDA layer within the 100 h cycle. It should be attributed to the extra thickness of PEGDA layer hinders the transportation of lithium ions, leading to the larger polarization at the beginning. In addition, the PEGDA layer without electrochemical activation that has poor ionic conductivity initially also gives a large interfacial resistance to the cell. Interestingly, the electrode polarization gradually disappears when stable lithium ion channels are generated inside the PEGDA layer. After 100 h cycle, the overpotential of the cell without protective layer becomes larger. On the contrary, the cell using PEGDA layer still exhibits the excellent stability with a flat polarization voltage up to 700 h cycling. Therefore, the better cyclic stability of Li||Li coin cell is achieved due to the isolation of the redox reaction between lithium metal and LLTO ceramic in PVH-15 electrolyte by the PEGDA layer.

To investigate the effect of PEGDA protective layer on the morphology change for the cycled lithium electrode, the surface and cross-sectional SEM is analyzed. The fresh lithium anode with PEGDA layer in Fig. 7 (d1) has a smoother surface than the fresh lithium anode without protective layer in Fig. 7 (b1). From the cross-sectional SEM image in Fig. 7 (b2) for bare lithium and Fig. 7 (d2) for coated lithium, the thickness of coated one becomes thicker, indicating that the PEGDA protective layer was successfully in situ polymerized on the surface lithium anode. Further verified by the cross-sectional image of PEGDA protective layer in Fig. S9, the thickness of 25 μm for the coated layer with a compact structure largely minimizes the impact on the transport of lithium ions, helping to improve the cycling stability of assembled cells.

However, the morphology of the lithium anode without PEGDA layer changes after only 230 h cycle in Fig. 7 (c). Many deposited by-products with loose structure appear on the surface of bare lithium in Fig. 7 (c1), caused by the accumulated lithium dendrites and a small amount of electrolyte decomposition products. This is mainly due to the intense side reaction between lithium and LLTO in the composite electrolyte that aggravates the generation of dead lithium and the decomposition of trace liquid electrolyte. Worse still, a volume expansion can be clearly seen from the cross-sectional SEM in Fig. 7 (c2) for the cycled lithium electrode compared with the fresh one in Fig. 7 (b2), which should be the reason for the poor cycling stability of Li||Li coin cell.

On the contrary, the morphology of protective lithium anode is different from the bare one in Fig. 7 (e) after 700 h cycle. Although some cracks can be found on the surface PEGDA protective layer, it maintains relatively smooth and compact structure without dendrites or obvious decomposition products in Fig. 7 (e1). Small volume expansion in Fig. 7 (e2) can be also observed compared with fresh one, but the cross-sectional structure keeps tightly connected, which will not affect the dissolution/deposition of lithium ions. It seems that the PEGDA protective layer constructed by in situ polymerization not only blocks the reaction between lithium metal and LLTO ceramic in PVH-15 electrolyte by the excellent reduction stability of PEGDA polymer itself, but also makes the lithium ions be uniformly deposited/dissolved on the surface lithium anode during repeated charge/discharge processes. Therefore, the coated layer on the surface lithium anode effectively inhibits the formation of lithium dendrites, yielding the super cyclic stability of Li||Li coin cell.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical performance of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cell
ce:section.ce:para:
To further demonstrate the contribution of PEGDA protective layer on the surface lithium anode, the long-term cyclic stability of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cells assembled with PVH-15 electrolyte was evaluated under 0.2C rate between the voltage range of 3 V and 4.35 V at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 8
(a), the initial discharge capacity of full cell with PEGDA protective layer is 176 mAh g−1, which slowly fades to 159.4 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, maintaining a good capacity retention of 90.6%. The corresponding charge/discharge curves in Fig. 8 (b) illustrate that the voltage platform does not decrease significantly with the increased cycles, caused by the lower polarization of cathode contributed by the gelled PEGDA interlayer. However, the discharge capacity drops sharply for the full-cell using bare lithium anode, indicating that a violent interface reaction does occur inside the battery, leading to the structure damage for electrode and/or electrolyte material. Therefore, the protective lithium anode contributes its stability to high-voltage Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cells.

To further verify the effect of trace liquid electrolyte on the cell performance, the cyclic stability of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full-cell wetted with different contents of liquid electrolyte are exhibited in Fig. S10. Compared to the cell without liquid electrolyte, the wetted cells all yield higher initial specific discharge capacity and capacity retention, which increase with the amount of liquid electrolyte. However, there is no significant difference in the cycling performance for the cell with 2 μL cm−2 or 4 μL cm−2 liquid electrolytes. Therefore, the trace liquid electrolyte with the amount of 2 μL cm−2 is sufficient to improve the interface compatibility between electrode and electrolyte, and ensures the safety performance of the battery simultaneously. The result is also in accordance with the ionic conductivity. Additionally, the interfacial resistance in solid battery can be largely deduced by adding 2 μL cm−2 liquid electrolyte, which effectively improves the ionic conduction behavior at the solid electrolyte/electrode interface.

Fig. 8 (c) shows the rate performance of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cell using PVH-15 electrolyte with protected lithium anode. The corresponding charge/discharge curves at different rates are presented in Fig. 8 (d). It can be seen that the discharge capacity of Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cells gradually decreases with the increased current rate, due to the enhanced electrode polarization. Even at a high current density of 2C, the battery still has a discharge capacity of 115.2 mAh g−1, retaining 66% of capacity at 0.2C rate (173.4 mAh g−1). When the current density returns to 0.2C, the discharge capacity backs to 167.8 mAh g−1, showing the excellent capacity recovery capabilities. The excellent cycling performance and rate capability should be ascribed from the addition of fast ion conductors of LLTO, which forms lithium ion transport channels inside the solid electrolyte to ensure the rapid transport of lithium ions. The protective effect of PEGDA layer on lithium anode also provides a stable interface for the battery and the wetting interface by trace liquid electrolyte both reduce the interface resistance, finally contributing to the electrochemical stability of assembled coin cell. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of the ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte can be significantly improved through the simple in situ polymerization method to construct the gel polymer layer on the surface of the lithium metal anode, which gives a facile way to promote the application of high safety solid electrolyte in the high-energy-density LMBs.

Ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte with excellent mechanical and electrochemical properties by embedding perovskite-type LLTO fast ionic conductors into P(VdF-HFP) polymer was prepared to be used in high-energy-density LMBs. To avoid the adverse reaction between LLTO particles and lithium anode, PEGDA protective interlayer is constructed by facile in situ polymerization. The designed solid electrolyte, wetted by trace liquid electrolyte and combined with unique protective layer, yields more than 700 h cycle life in Li||Li symmetric cells and retains 90.6% of initial capacity after 200 cycles in high-voltage Li||LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 full cell. The reduced interface resistance of ceramic-in-polymer solid electrolyte and lithium anode by PEGDA interlayer that facilitates the fast transfer of lithium ions through its −CH2−CH2−O− segments, while the high oxidative stability of solid electrolyte assures the improved electrochemical stability for 4.35 V high-voltage cathode. Thus, the unique combination of solid electrolyte and treated lithium anode enables LMBs to achieve the breakthroughs the contradiction performances between high safety and high energy density, giving a bright future to the fast development of next-generation batteries.

Min He: Data curation, Investigation, Writing – original draft. Changyong Mo: Data curation, Investigation, Methodology. Zecheng Lu: Data curation, Investigation, Methodology. Yonghao Huang: Data curation, Investigation. Zhancai Qiu: Investigation. Weishan Li: Resources, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing. Youhao Liao: Conceptualization, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing.
